awd_titl_txt: Developing STEM Master Teachers to Lead Digital Conversion in K-12 Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
This Noyce Track 3 Master Teaching Fellowship project seeks to address the growing national need for mathematics and science teachers who are equipped to provide instruction in digitally-rich classrooms.  It builds upon previous work at the University of Rochester to develop teacher leaders.  It also takes advantage of a newly formed Consortium of the University of Rochester and several school districts in upstate New York, that are working together toward district-wide digital conversion.  The project will develop a group of teacher leaders, known as Master Teaching Fellows, to guide district-wide digital conversion efforts in high-need school districts.  Digital conversion is a comprehensive process that that provides each student with a tablet or laptop computer and uses these computers to enhance student learning.  Each Fellow will engage in a five-year program involving 41 credit hours of graduate coursework accompanied by related mentored experiences.  Completion of this program will lead to an Advanced Certificate in Digitally-Rich Teaching in K-12 Schools, which is approved by the New York State Education Department.  In addition, the Master Teaching Fellows will receive annual salary supplements, as they persist as classroom teachers who demonstrate effective use of digital resources.  Through its project evaluation, the project will generate knowledge about how to prepare teacher leaders who can support implementation of high-quality, technology-enriched STEM instruction by others.

Twenty experienced and exemplary mathematics and science teachers with master's degrees will be recruited from six high-need, small school districts (including three primarily rural districts) that are members of the Western New York Digital Conversion Consortium.  This project will capitalize on the long-standing partnership established in previous Master Teaching Fellow projects between the University of Rochester (through its Warner School of Education and STEM departments), the Geneva City School District, the Newark Central School District, and the non-profit Rochester Museum & Science Center.  It will also add new partners: East Irondequoit Central School District, a local pioneer in digital conversion, and three additional high-need rural districts from the Consortium (Dansville, Penn Yan, and Auburn).  With more rigorous learning standards and the challenge of integrating new technology with instruction, it is imperative that researchers and practitioners collaborate to develop deep understanding of what is needed to achieve the full potential of digitally-rich teaching to improve student achievement, especially in STEM.  This project will contribute evidence to the STEM education community about preparation of STEM teacher leaders to integrate digital resources into instruction, to lead their districts in digital conversion efforts, and to use technology to improve STEM instruction and increase student engagement.  This program for the preparation of "digitally-rich STEM master teachers" has the potential to serve as a replicable model by other universities in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview and Context

This University of Rochester (UR) Noyce Track 3 Master Teaching Fellows (MTF) program was awarded in 2018 to build and expand on two previously successful Noyce MTF programs at the UR.  Designed and funded pre-Covid, the project was fortuitously intended to develop a cadre of master teachers to grow and develop their knowledge, use, and leadership towards incorporating the use of digital technologies to support all students’ learning in STEM.  Twenty experienced and exemplary K-12 mathematics and science teachers completed the five-year program from seven high-need school districts, five of which were rural districts. Through a combination of graduate coursework, mentored support, and extensive professional learning, these 20 master teachers developed their knowledge and skills in (a) STEM content and pedagogy, (b) STEM professional learning (including coaching), (c) the use of digital technologies to increase access to STEM, and (d) leadership in STEM and digitally-rich practices. We fostered and leveraged partnerships with the UR Warner School of Education, the UR Earth and Environmental Science department, and the Rochester Museum and Science Center.

 

Based on their engagement in this program, all 20 fellows earned a NYSED-approved Certificate in Digitally-Rich Teaching and a NYSED-approved Advanced Certificate in Teacher Leadership.  In addition, eight fellows earned their NYS Administrative Certification through additional coursework at the Warner School.  The table below summarizes the fellows’ areas of focus and accomplishments. 

 

UR Noyce Master Teacher Fellows 2018 – 2024

 

Discipline

  

Grade Bands

  

Advanced Certificates

  

Math

12

Elem

7

NYS K-12 Administrative Certification

8

Science

8

Sec

13

Advanced Certificate in Teacher Leadership

20

 

      

Digitally-rich Teaching & Learning Certificate

20

 

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

 

The project has made a significant impact on the fellows themselves as teachers and as leaders, on students in the fellows’ classrooms, and on fellows’ colleagues and school communities.  This project was in its second year when the Covid-19 pandemic hit.  As a result, our fellows were well-positioned to help their districts navigate digital learning and technology. 

 

By the end of the program, all fellows rated themselves as either "very knowledgeable" or "knowledgeable" of student learning in high-needs settings, with the majority (63%) rating themselves as "very knowledgeable."  Fellows also indicated an increase in their use of reform-minded teaching practices in their math and science classrooms, implying that more students in the fellows' districts were experiencing higher-quality math and/or science learning experiences than previously.

 

For example, two projects designed and implemented by fellows explicitly illustrate broadening opportunities for students.  One project built a maple sugar program on their district campus and another created a “Girls who STEM” club in their district.  Both projects brought in relevant stakeholders and experts (e.g., local engineers, scientists, and maple producers) to engage with students.  The projects provided students access to professionals in STEM fields, potentially influencing careers interests.  

 

This program also demonstrated fellows’ impact on their colleagues as they engaged in conversations about reform-based teaching, collaborated with other teachers to improve their practices, provided mentoring to early career teachers, led professional learning initiatives/efforts, drove instructional and curricular innovations, initiated system-wide school reform, and played an important role in building a professional learning community in their schools/districts.

 

Lastly, the broader impact of this program can be explicitly seen in a recently funded (2023) Noyce Conference Grant to develop an ongoing and sustained Noyce Northeast Professional Learning Network.  Six of the Noyce fellows from this program are engaged as part of the “Teacher Leader Cadre” providing professional learning and mentoring support for other Noyce scholars, fellows, and alumni across the Northeast.  This includes facilitating sessions at the Noyce Northeast Conferences, leading ongoing online Professional Learning Communities, facilitating online video clubs, and providing online content-focused coaching to current and past Noyce participants.

 

Products

In addition to all of the activities, showcases, and professional learning provided by fellows in districts, this program produced three “STEM for All” video showcases (e.g., https://stemforall2019.videohall.com/presentations/1522), a book chapter showcasing the power of teacher leaders using case studies from this program (Bond, 2021), five presentations at state-wide technology conferences, three presentations at AAAS Annual Noyce Summits, and one presentation at a national math conference (NCSM).

 

Most notable, however, will be the publication of an open-access PressBook that will provide the primary activities and assignments that fellows engaged in over the course of this program in service to preparing STEM teacher leaders to meaningfully and productively integrate digital resources in instruction and leverage technology to improve STEM instruction.  In addition, six fellows are co-authors telling the story of their journeys through this program as they grew as STEM teacher leaders equipped with a toolkit of instructional approaches that leverage digitally-rich classroom environments.  This open-source book will be especially helpful for those interested in developing teacher leadership programs and for teachers who are interested in engaging in similar efforts.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2024
Modified by: Cynthia Callard
